snippet.textDisplay:
Oh, but imagine if they had been offered antibiotics and modern medicine - and they had still turned their noses up at it.
There are parents who deny their children medical treatment, and condemn them to slow painful deaths as a result.
So imagine the Na'vi were like that. Why, you might conclude that such a culture deserved to hammered into the ground. And the people doing it would arguably be heroes...
Funny how Cameron never brought this up, isn't it?
snippet.textOriginal:
Oh, but imagine if they had been offered antibiotics and modern medicine - and they had still turned their noses up at it.
There are parents who deny their children medical treatment, and condemn them to slow painful deaths as a result.
So imagine the Na'vi were like that. Why, you might conclude that such a culture deserved to hammered into the ground. And the people doing it would arguably be heroes...
Funny how Cameron never brought this up, isn't it?

snippet.textOriginal:

snippet.textDisplay: To me the main reason is fear of drowning. Avatar 2 is so realistic it makes you feel like you are drowning in front of hundreds of people and everybody is watching a huge screen and you are now inside the screen. You are inside the scene with this amazing guy and you are looking at him and he is having a conversation with a whale. And then you have a moment of fresh air to breathe. That, sir, is beyond terrifying. Avatar 2 terrifies you into staying away from the cinema for fear of feeling like a small fish in a cage. But ironically it is also James Cameron´s most important message - we are, however significant we think we are, at the mercy of the elements, of nature, and for a while life feels like a fish tank you are trapped in until you have these beautiful, precious moments where you can enjoy the breath of fresh air - where air becomes more valuable than ever. I loved it. But I was terrified of going, because of this innate fear of drowning. Thanks for your video man. Kind regards from Ásgeir in Iceland.
snippet.textOriginal: To me the main reason is fear of drowning. Avatar 2 is so realistic it makes you feel like you are drowning in front of hundreds of people and everybody is watching a huge screen and you are now inside the screen. You are inside the scene with this amazing guy and you are looking at him and he is having a conversation with a whale. And then you have a moment of fresh air to breathe. That, sir, is beyond terrifying. Avatar 2 terrifies you into staying away from the cinema for fear of feeling like a small fish in a cage. But ironically it is also James Cameron´s most important message - we are, however significant we think we are, at the mercy of the elements, of nature, and for a while life feels like a fish tank you are trapped in until you have these beautiful, precious moments where you can enjoy the breath of fresh air - where air becomes more valuable than ever. I loved it. But I was terrified of going, because of this innate fear of drowning. Thanks for your video man. Kind regards from Ásgeir in Iceland.

snippet.textDisplay: Mind blowing. Indeed true it seems.
snippet.textOriginal: Mind blowing. Indeed true it seems.

snippet.textDisplay: With the Avatar films, the viewer has to appreciate individual aspects of the film, aka the visuals. Way of Water was never going to have the impact that the first one did in that respect. The whole is less than the sum of the parts. Most good films, the viewer does not have to do this for. With Avatar, you have to process the film and intentionally certain aspects of it. I think it is difficult art because of this, which a good film ought not be. Good films may have challenging themes or characters, but they shouldn't be hard to appreciate on a fundamental level. They should FEEL good without much effort on the part of the viewer.
snippet.textOriginal: With the Avatar films, the viewer has to appreciate individual aspects of the film, aka the visuals. Way of Water was never going to have the impact that the first one did in that respect. The whole is less than the sum of the parts. Most good films, the viewer does not have to do this for. With Avatar, you have to process the film and intentionally certain aspects of it. I think it is difficult art because of this, which a good film ought not be. Good films may have challenging themes or characters, but they shouldn't be hard to appreciate on a fundamental level. They should FEEL good without much effort on the part of the viewer.

snippet.textDisplay:
The messaging even rings more hollow when you realize that James Cameron absolutely has the money to buy up enough land to form his own commune and go live as one with the land in that commune. But does he? No. He has fancy cars, at least one very nice house, goes to restaurants where waiters serve him food, has other people prepare food for him that he didn't hunt or ranch or farm....

He uses human technology of the most advanced and sophisticated sort to take tourist runs to the bottom of the ocean. And that's great! But it belies his message in these movies. Heck, one easy way to say "There's Good In Human Tech, Too," would have been to have the ability to explore the bottom of the ocean for longer be something the Na'vi were jealous of Spider for. Make Spider's survival tech BETTER for exploring than the Na'vi natural talents, on the basis taht it already is helping him survive their world. This would even let him keep his "heroic humans" distinct from his "wicked humans," since Spider appreciates Na'vi society.
snippet.textOriginal:
The messaging even rings more hollow when you realize that James Cameron absolutely has the money to buy up enough land to form his own commune and go live as one with the land in that commune. But does he? No. He has fancy cars, at least one very nice house, goes to restaurants where waiters serve him food, has other people prepare food for him that he didn't hunt or ranch or farm....

He uses human technology of the most advanced and sophisticated sort to take tourist runs to the bottom of the ocean. And that's great! But it belies his message in these movies. Heck, one _easy_ way to say "There's Good In Human Tech, Too," would have been to have the ability to explore the bottom of the ocean for longer be something the Na'vi were jealous of Spider for. Make Spider's survival tech BETTER for exploring than the Na'vi natural talents, on the basis taht it already is helping him survive their world. This would even let him keep his "heroic humans" distinct from his "wicked humans," since Spider appreciates Na'vi society.

snippet.textDisplay:
PRepare to lose it!

It's "The Last Samurai Dances With Space Smurfs." There.

Though the big issue I have with it is that the behavior of the characters doesn't align with their motivations, except for the main character if you paint him as a complete worthless narcissist with no business being the main character unless this is supposed to be a tragedy with him as villain protagonist.

He had one job, and he didn't do it. And that was to the detriment of both the humans and the Na'vi. He made zero effort to inform them of what the humans wanted, and why, nor to negotiate a way to get it without causing problems for the Na'vi. He didn't even warn them of it, let alone suggest ways they could work together or trade or what-have-you. He did NOTHING he was supposed to do.

And the corporate dudes failed utterly to listen to their science advisors, and their science advisors didn't try to explain anything before whining about not being listened to. Nobody acted like the kind of person who would last 5 days into a training seminar for the first round of candidate trials to go on a super-expensive mission like this one.

And all of that is to make sure the plot goes into the toilet so that we can have the hackneyed "humans and corporations bad; nature and magic plants good" message, which doesn't even land very well because to MAKE the nature-good thing have any weight, they had to give a magic psychic bond to all natives of the planet, which isn't present on Earth in a way that lets the message translate. "If you all could snap your fingers and make food, then there would be no world hunger!" is the same level of messaging about "greed bad, feeding people good."

Ironically, I think the second movie has more interesting plots, but would've been better served as a miniseries. The coming-of-age story coupled to the stranger-in-a-strange-land story that contrasts Na'vi cultural differences between each other with human need to adapt to the planet and new cultures was actually pretty cool.

snippet.textDisplay: I feel like the lack of subtlety is really damaging, lots of terrible things that happen aren't caused by 'evil people being evil' but normal people making the choice that's easier for them and collectively adding together to cause terrible harm, removing all the nuance to this extent stops any examination of why people are making some of the decisions that look damaging

snippet.textDisplay: OK. I cannot take this bs anymore. I have to stop watching this. Usually I do enjoy your videos, but this is painful to listen to. I am not arguing that the Avatar movies are some sort of masterpieces storytelling-wise - they are not. They actually are lazy and superficial in terms of the plot. BUT. You are failing to do, what you are critiquing here: to set your personal ideology aside. What it sounds like to me is that you feel offended by the point and critique the films are making - like many other people if you start talking to them about e.g. the climate crisis or their meat consumption. People don’t want to have their warped versions of realy challagend or to give up their way of life, even though it is proven to destroy our very own basis of existence as a species (and not "just" the „beauty of nature“) and react emotionally and try to shift the blame or to proof, why their way of life in reality is fine (even though it is not) - especially by trying to pick apart the person who is stating the opposite point by trying to find faults in them. Because if they are not morally impeccable, then you don’t have to listen to what they are stating, even if what they are stating are undeniable facts. Right? You can stay in denial and don’t have to feel responsible or, shocker, feel obligated to actually do something about it. This is what you are doing here. What is your point…? That the movie is demonising the system, that is responsible for the destruction of our ecosystem and therefor for unmeasurable suffering that is already happening and of what is way more to come in the next years? To stay with the picture this word is painting: so, you are mad that the movie demonises the demon…? Just because it is not a perfect movie? Well. The cognitive dissonance seems to be strong with this one, eh.

snippet.textDisplay:
Blomkamp's clumsy political messages make his films bad imo.

Avatar was good as a 3D spectacle but meh as a film. Didn't bother to watch A2.

I suspect it's not so much the clumsiness that people hate as the message itself.
snippet.textOriginal:

snippet.textDisplay:
The irony is that for natural way of life, people who now survive because of modern society have to die in droves, weak children will die without any modern medicine to save them, overall life expectancy drops.

Also wars and death will be abundant, nobility and/or warlords will rule the people, while living in luxury, while the low peasants are at nature's mercy.

There will not be a magic tree to save everyone, few exceptions only because of the genetic lottery that fuels the evolution. Individual only matters for the rulers, the society for the peasants.

Then natural selection drives your species into inevitable extinction, so that other animal can evolve to replace your species in your niche...
snippet.textOriginal:

Then natural selection drives your species into inevitable extinction, so that other animal can evolve to replace your species in your niche...

snippet.textDisplay:
ye i can agree , while i appreciate the honesty of the way avatar presents its thoughts about x stuff when it wants to say something rather then being a tipy toe ''dont hurt anyones fee fee's!'' or the other ''totally not saying anything but.. well..this'' etc... i do wish it could been made a bit more organically ^^ though did it realy paint all the humans as bad ? did the human splinter group in the first not touch on how all those blokes hade friends or family at home etc ..but well one destroyed planet bio-sphere is enough ? :/

though ..''to focused on progress'' not sure that is a word i add with the stuff the first movie at least touched on , the 'consumer' ye thank you i am a CUSTOMER not a 'CONSUMER' hashtag cattle projection ..but progress is not a word i latch with the ''tis self destructive'' talk of the movie more like ''progress , but make sure to clean up/heal if you burn things in the process'' or such

havent seen the second movie yet though so.. hmm , maby about time i get it.

snippet.textDisplay:
I've never liked Avatar since day 1 and never struggled to pin down my reasons, both Avatar films capitalize on sensationalism, where they throw every despicable trait onto the villain, make the audience hate them to gut then let protagonists destroy these villains so the audience experience a cheap dopamine high. It's super lazy writing and completely unrealistic and childish, in fact this level of character development is an insult to the audience's intelligence.

The central theme also panders too much toward conspiracy people, its easy to sell the idea that people without technology live much happier lives, and it resonates with modern-day leftwing hippies, but it couldn't be further from the truth. With an average life expectancy of below 30 years, most modern people would not want to live in those eras realistically. Still, instead of bringing these nuances to the screen, the plot overly romanticise the notion of nature good, technology bad, in order to tell more tickets.

It also does a great disservice to scientists in general, by putting them together with capitalists and military extremists, which is very unfair and inaccurate to the general perspective and stance of the scientific community, they more than anyone else, including leftwing hippies, understands the value of nature, and are at the forefront of fighting against climate change, technology driven by science is not against nature and its preservation.

It's super lazy writing and completely unrealistic and childish, in fact this level of character development is an insult to the audience's intelligence.

The central theme also panders too much toward conspiracy people, its easy to sell the idea that people without technology live much happier lives, and it resonates with modern-day leftwing hippies, but it couldn't be further from the truth. With an average life expectancy of below 30 years, most modern people would not want to live in those eras realistically. snippet.textDisplay:
The one thing that did actually bug me ALOT at the end of the movie.
The entire ending of the fight section hinges on most of them drowning in the boat as it floods.
Yet earlier in the movie AND IN THE DAMN SCENE they already fixed this issue with the jellyfish creatures that literally allow you to breath under water.
Couldn’t they just, I don’t know always keep one nearby like how spider always keeps his oxygen mask on.
Could have saved that entire ending there and then.
Could have even increased the fighting underwater if both of them had one of them mfs strapped to their backs.
